name: Maximum connection times
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~CiesTurnConnTimeMax param) (~CiesApplyTurnConnTimeMax param) (~CiesSplitConnTimeMaxPerBase param) (~CiesApplySplitConnTimeMaxPerBase param) (~SierraCiesNightConnTimeMax0 param) (~SierraCiesNightConnTimeMax1 param) (~CiesApplyNightConnTimeMax param) (~CiesIntlConnTimeMax param) (~CiesApplyIntlConnTimeMax param) (~CiesConnTimeMax param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
Connections between flights must be shorter than [CiesConnTimeMax]. This limit can be overridden as follows:
- [CiesApplyIntlConnTimeMax | switch] When at least one of the two connecting flights is international, the connection must be shorter than [CiesIntlConnTimeMax].
- [CiesApplyNightConnTimeMax | switch] If any part of the connection touches [SierraCiesNightConnTimeMax1], the connection must be shorter than [SierraCiesNightConnTimeMax0].
- [CiesApplySplitConnTimeMaxPerBase | switch] If the connection occurs inside a [split duty](split-duty-def), the maximum duration depends on the base station of the pairing, as specified in [CiesSplitConnTimeMaxPerBase this table].
- [CiesApplyTurnConnTimeMax | switch] When the crew follows the aircraft, the connection must be shorter than [CiesTurnConnTimeMax]

name: Minimum connection time for a turn
userDescription:
The minimum allowed connection time on a [turn](turn-def) is [CieConnTimeTurn]. 

This rule is enabled/disabled along with the [Minimum connection time for aircraft change](CiesApplyConnTimeMin) rule. When the minimum is greater than 0h00, it overrides any generic, station, or region minimum connection times that have been defined in the Minimum connection time for aircraft change rule.

name: Minimum connection time for aircraft changes
userDescription:
Allow a connection with a change of aircraft only when the connection meets or exceeds the minimum time on ground requirement for crew members, as defined in [SierraConnTimeMin this table].

[CiesApplyThrsConnection | switch] Display a caution on pairings with one or more connections that come within [CiesThrsTimeConn] of the limits defined in this rule.

When the crew is changing aircraft, [CieConnTimeMinPanelToTurn this table] allows to turn on or off the verification of minimum connection duration.

name: Forbid short operating-deadhead turns
userDescription: When a [turn](turn-def) is shorter than [CiesShortActiveDeadheadTurn], an operating flight cannot be followed by a deadhead on the same aircraft; and a deadhead cannot be followed by an operating flight on the same aircraft.

name: Turn definition
userDescription: A connection where crew members follow the airplane.

name: Crew swap definition
userDescription: A crew swap is when the crew for an airplane changes at a connection/layover station.

name: No crew swap for through flights
userDescription: Crew members cannot change airplanes on connections between two flights with the same flight number.

name: Split duty definition
userDescription: A split duty is a duty period that has one or more long on-ground breaks within the FDP. These breaks provide rest opportunities that may allow the FDP to be extended.

name: Duty composition
userDescription: Duties created by the solver must follow one of these [SierraDutyCompositions duty construction patterns].

name: Maximum airplane changes per duty and per pairing
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~SierraCiesThrsAcChg1 param) (~SierraCiesThrsAcChg0 param) (~CiesApplyThrsAcChg param) (~CiesAcChgBetweenActiveLegOnly param) (~CiesAcChgDuration param) (~CiesAcChgNb param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
The maximum number of times that crew members can switch to a different airplane within the same duty or pairing is defined in [CiesAcChgNb this table]. 

To further control the number of aircraft changes within the limits defined above, a [penalty on aircraft changes in a duty period](CiesApplyAcChgPen) can be applied. 

This rule is only applied to airplane changes where the duration of the connection is [CiesAcChgDuration] or less. 

[CiesAcChgBetweenActiveLegOnly | switch] Only apply this rule to airplane changes between operating flights; connections from/to a deadhead are not included. 

[CiesApplyThrsAcChg | switch] Display cautions on duties that have between [SierraCiesThrsAcChg0] and [SierraCiesThrsAcChg1] airplane changes.

name: Apply flight deck rules during the solve
userDescription:
When on, rules that mention **flight deck only** are applied during the solve.

When off, rules that mention **cabin only** are applied.

Rules that do not specifically mention **flight deck only** or **cabin only** are not affected by this rule.

name: Duty and rest time adjustments for ground delays
userDescription:
Subtract the reduction times defined in [CiesGroundDelayDutyTimeReduction this table] for each arrival or departure at specific stations from the maximum allowed duty time. This will lower the duty time maximum during planning, to prevent the duty time from being increased due to delays during operations.  

[CiesApplyGroundDelayRestTimeExtension | switch] Extend the minimum rest time at a layover after a duty that was reduced because of a ground delay. This extension will only be applied if: 
- The layover duration is less than the minimum rest time plus the duty reduction defined for the layover station. 
- Duty reductions are enabled.

name: CDO duty definition
userDescription: A duty that contains at least one [CDO connection](cdo-connection-def) is considered a CDO duty.

name: Forbid CDO connections at certain stations
userDescription: [CDO connections](cdo-connection-def) are not allowed at any of the stations defined in [CiesCDORestrictStations this list].

name: Long connection definition
userDescription: A long connection has a minimum duration of [CiesRoomTimeMin].

name: Prevent non-CDO night connections
userDescription:
For non-[CDO pairings](cdo-pairing-def), do not allow connections that occur between [SierraCiesNonCDONightConnInterval0] and [SierraCiesNonCDONightConnInterval1].

[CiesApplyNonCDONightConnCharterException | switch] Do not apply this rule to operating charter-bound connections.

name: Maximum rest time
userDescription:
Limit the duration of rest periods to a maximum of [SierraCiesRestTimeMax1].

[CiesApplyCautionRestTimeMax | switch] Display a caution on any pairing with a rest period that exceeds the desired limit of [SierraCiesRestTimeMax0]. Station-specific exceptions to these limits are defined in [CiesStationsRestTimeMax this table].
[CiesUseLayoverTimeInRestTimeMaxRule | switch] For the purposes of this rule, measure rest time from the debriefing end time of a duty, to the briefing start time of the next duty.

name: Reduce rest duration by transit times
userDescription: Deduct the time it takes to travel between the airport and the hotel during a layover when calculating rest time.

name: Minimum durations for layovers between INT and DOM duties
userDescription:
Use the durations in [SierraLayoverTimeMin this table] to determine the minimum layover required between international and domestic duties.
The Generic values in this table define standard limits. Exceptions for specific regions, countries or stations take precedence over generic durations.
When other minimum rest rules are on at the same time as this one, the most restrictive (smallest) duration will be used.

name: Domestic duty
userDescription: A domestic duty is one that does not visit a station in another country.

name: International duty
userDescription: An international duty visits at least one station in another country during a flight, layover, or connection.

name: Mark rests that are close to the minimum duration
userDescription: Display a caution on each rest period with a duration that comes within [CiesThrsTimeRestMin] of the minimum required duration.

name: Only schedule rests at night
userDescription:
Only allow layovers that cross [CiesNightRestLimit]. This is to encourage the solver to assign layovers that occur during the night.

[CiesNightRestLimitByAcclimatizedTime | switch] Use the local time at the layover station for the crossover time for night layovers.

name: Maximum number of days crossed by a pairing
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~CiesApplyMidnightSameDay param) (~CiesEndingTimeLastDuty param) (~CiesApplyEndingTimeLastDutyInterval param) (~CiesEndingTimeLastDuty param) (~CiesApplyEndingTimeLastDuty param) (~CiesTripDayMaxForSpecialStations param) (~CiesUseTripDayMaxForSpecialStations param) (~CiesTripDayMaxForSpecialAcTypes param) (~CiesUseTripDayMaxForSpecialAcTypes param) (~CiesTripDayMax param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
Limit the number of calendar days crossed by a [domestic](domestic-pairing-def) or [international pairing](international-pairing-def) depending on its departure station, as specified in [CiesTripDayMax this table].

Apply the following exceptions to this rule: 
- [CiesUseTripDayMaxForSpecialAcTypes | switch] Use the limits defined in [CiesTripDayMaxForSpecialAcTypes this table] when pairings are flown on specific types of aircraft. 
- [CiesUseTripDayMaxForSpecialStations | switch] Use the limits defined in [CiesTripDayMaxForSpecialStations this table] when specific stations are visited during the pairing. 

When both of these tables are enabled, the most restrictive rule will be applied to pairings that operate on one of the specified aircraft types that also visits one of the specified stations. 

[CiesApplyEndingTimeLastDuty | switch] Do not allow the last duty in a pairing to end after [CiesEndingTimeLastDuty]. 

[CiesApplyEndingTimeLastDutyInterval | switch] If a pairing has reached the maximum number of allowed days, forbid the pairing from ending between [CiesEndingTimeLastDuty] and [midnight](midnight-def). 

[CiesApplyMidnightSameDay | switch] When a pairing departs/arrives exactly at [midnight](midnight-def), consider it to have departed/arrived on the last second of the current day. When this switch is off, the "midnight" instant belongs to the next day.  So, a pairing that departs/arrives at midnight will be considered to have departed/arrived at the beginning of a new day.

name: Midnight definition
userDescription: **Midnight** is the boundary between the end of one day and the start of the next. [CiesMidnightDefLdt This table] defines when "midnight" occurs at specific stations, in local base time.

name: International pairing
userDescription:
Any pairing that visits at least one station in another country during a flight, layover, or connection is an international pairing.

[CiesApplyTripDayMaxIntByLayover | switch] Only pairings with at least one **layover** at a station in another country are international.

name: Domestic pairing
userDescription: A domestic pairing is one that does not visit a station in another country.

name: Start and end pairings at the same base station
userDescription:
Force pairings to start and end at the same base station; layovers at the base are not allowed. 

[PgCodomicileBase | switch] Allow pairings to start or end at a base's codomicile.

[PgStartEndSame | switch] A pairing's start and end stations must be identical.

name: Minimum rest time for two consecutive layovers
userDescription: The combined rest time of any two consecutive layovers must be at least [CiesConsecutiveRestTimeMin].

name: Allow deadhead duties at the start, middle, and/or end of a pairing
userDescription:
Allow deadhead-only duties in a pairing at the beginning, middle or end of a pairing, according to the following selections.

[SierraCiesApplyAllowDeadheadDuty0 | switch] Allow deadhead-only duties at the beginning of a pairing.
[SierraCiesApplyAllowDeadheadDuty1 | switch] Allow deadhead-only duties anywhere in the middle of a pairing.
[SierraCiesApplyAllowDeadheadDuty2 | switch] Allow deadhead-only duties at the end of a pairing.

Note: If you want to forbid a deadhead-only duty, remove that duty type from the [Duty Composition rule](CiesApplyDutyComposition).

name: Forbid deadhead-layover-deadhead duty sequences
userDescription: Do not allow layovers between two deadhead-only duties.

name: Accommodation selection, costs, and room calculations
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~CiesApplyTransportCost param) (~SierraCiesFARoomCrewTimeRange1 param) (~SierraCiesFARoomCrewTimeRange0 param) (~CiesApplyFARoomCrew param) (~SierraCiesDayRoomCrewTimeRange1 param) (~SierraCiesDayRoomCrewTimeRange0 param) (~CiesApplyDayRoomCrew param) (~SierraCiesMaxCrewMemberPerHotelRoom1 param) (~CiesStationDayRoomTimeMin param) (~CiesHotelOverlapValue param) (~CiesApplyHotelOverlap param) (~SierraCiesMaxCrewMemberPerHotelRoom0 param) (~CiesRoomHotelTime param) (~CiesApplyValidHotelOnly param) (~CiesApplyValidHotel param) (~CiesApplyHotelRoomOnSBY param) (~CiesApplyHotelRoomOnCDO param) (~CiesLongRoomTimeMin param) (~CiesUseLongRoomTimeMin param) (~CiesRoomTimeMin param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
**Use the nightly rate** for each accommodation when building a **pairing**.

### When to provide accommodation

**Provide accommodations** for any break that is [CiesRoomTimeMin] or longer. 

[CiesUseLongRoomTimeMin | switch] Only use a **City accommodation **when a rest or connection is longer than [CiesLongRoomTimeMin]; otherwise, accommodation must be at the airport.
[CiesApplyHotelRoomOnCDO | switch] Allow hotel rooms for **[CDO duties](cdo-duty-def)**. 
[CiesApplyHotelRoomOnSBY | switch] Allow hotel rooms for **standby duties**.
[CiesApplyValidHotel | switch] Display an info icon on pairings that use **accommodations** that are **not defined in Accommodation data.**
[CiesApplyValidHotelOnly | switch] Only create layovers at stations where a contract with an accommodation provider is in effect on the layover dates. An infraction will be displayed on pairings with layover accommodations that are not under contract. 

### Calculating the number of nights

The **number of nights charged **by an accommodation is based on which "Nights calculated by" option is selected in the Data record for that accommodation.
When the **24-hour blocks **option is selected in the Data record, each [CiesRoomHotelTime] of layover is counted as one night. Typically, the value would be 24h00, but you can define any number of hours to represent one night.

### Overnight layovers

If a **layover** occurs **overnight**, assign a maximum of [SierraCiesMaxCrewMemberPerHotelRoom0] crew members per room. 
[CiesApplyHotelOverlap | switch] Use the same room booking when duties that require layovers at the same accommodation overlap. The amount of overlap that will require an additional night at the accommodation (for all stations and/or specific stations) is defined in [CiesHotelOverlapValue this table].

### Day layovers

For connections at stations where day rooms are available, **assign a [day room](day-room-def)** if the connection is longer than [CiesStationDayRoomTimeMin]. 

For day layovers, the **maximum crew members per room** is [SierraCiesMaxCrewMemberPerHotelRoom1].

[CiesApplyDayRoomCrew | switch] If a rest or connection occurs entirely between [SierraCiesDayRoomCrewTimeRange0] and [SierraCiesDayRoomCrewTimeRange1] allocate only **one day room for the whole flight deck crew**. 
[CiesApplyFARoomCrew | switch] If the duration of a rest or connection is between [SierraCiesFARoomCrewTimeRange0] and [SierraCiesFARoomCrewTimeRange1], allocate only **one day room for the whole cabin crew**.

### Transport costs

[CiesApplyTransportCost | switch] **Include the cost of transport** to/from accommodations when pairings are built. When this option is turned off, any transit costs specified for accommodations are ignored by the solver.

name: Day room definition
userDescription: A room at the airport where crew can rest, as opposed to having a longer rest at a hotel.

name: Credit costs
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~CieCreditFactorGnd param)  (~CieCreditFactorSby param) (~CiesCreditCostPerPosPerBase param) (~CieTripCreditMin param) (~CieCreditFactorTrip param) (~CieCreditFactorLeg param) (~CieDutyCreditMin param) (~CieCreditFactorDuty param) (~CieCreditFactorLeg param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
Use the highest of the following values as the **total credit time for a duty**:
- Total credits for all operating flights in the duty, multiplied by [CieCreditFactorLeg]. A value of 1.0 means that 100% of operating flight time will be counted as credits.
- Total duty time (report to release) multiplied by [CieCreditFactorDuty]. This is used for duties such as deadheads and standbys, where no credits are earned for brief/debrief periods.  
- The default minimum of [CieDutyCreditMin].


Use the highest of the following values as the **total credit time for a pairing**:
- Total credits for all operating flights in the duty, multiplied by [CieCreditFactorLeg]. A value of 1.0 means that 100% of operating flight time will be counted as credits.
- Total pairing time, from release to report, multiplied by [CieCreditFactorTrip]. 
- The default minimum of [CieTripCreditMin].


### Total credit costs for a pairing

The **cost per hour of credited work** for each position and each crew base in a pairing is defined in [CiesCreditCostPerPosPerBase this table]. The cost per position will be multiplied by the number of crew members in each position to calculate the total credit cost for the pairing.  

### Credits for standby and extended duties

Multiply the total hours of standby in a duty by [CieCreditFactorSby] to calculate **total standby credits**. 

 Apply a **minimum credit** of to **extended duties**. 

### Credits for deadheads

Multiply the duration of each ground deadhead in the duty by [CieCreditFactorGnd] to calculate the **total ground deadhead credits for a duty**.

Multiply deadhead block times by to calculate the **credits** that pilots will earn **for deadhead flights**.

To calculate the **block time credits** that cabin crew will earn **for deadheads**, multiply the total block time for all deadheads within a duty by the factors defined in. 

### Credits for multi-day rests

The **minimum credit hours** earned for each **[dead day](dead-day-def)** during a multi-day rest is .

### Credits for taxiing or moving between gates

The total credit hours earned when taxiing or moving an aircraft between gates **at specific bases** are defined in .

The credit hours earned when taxiing or moving an aircraft between gates** at outstations** (non-base) are defined in.

name: Dead day definition
userDescription: A dead day is a day off during a layover that earns credit. A dead day is measured [midnight](midnight-def)-to-midnight, local to the station where the rest occurs.

name: Deadhead costs
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~SierraPgWorldAreaDhCost1 param) (~SierraPgWorldAreaDhCost0 param) (~PgApplyWorldAreaDhCost param) (~PgInterpolateDefaultDhCostHour param) (~PgApplyDefaultDhCostHourAsFixed param) (~PgDefaultDhCostHour param) (~PgDefaultCieDhCostHour param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
The cost per crew member for **internal** deadheads are defined in [PgDefaultCieDhCostHour this table]. 

Default costs for **commercial** deadheads are defined in [PgDefaultDhCostHour this table]. 

[PgApplyDefaultDhCostHourAsFixed | switch] Apply the costs as they appear in the above tables. If this option is turned off, the costs will be multiplied by the duration of the deadhead.
[PgInterpolateDefaultDhCostHour | switch] Use a pro-rated cost for deadheads, based on the values in the above tables. Examples:
- For a deadhead with a duration of 0h45, use $\frac{3}{4}$ of the default cost for deadheads that are 1 hour or shorter. 
- For a deadhead with a duration of 6h30, use the default cost for deadheads that are between 6 and 7 hours, + $\frac{1}{2}$ of the difference between the default costs for deadheads that are up to 7 hours long, minus the cost for deadheads that are up to 6 hours long.  

[PgApplyWorldAreaDhCost | switch] Apply a default cost of [SierraPgWorldAreaDhCost0] for internal deadheads; and a default cost of [SierraPgWorldAreaDhCost1] for commercial deadheads. These soft cost values will be multiplied by the duration of the deadhead.

name: Penalty on aircraft changes in a duty period
userDescription:
Apply a soft cost penalty of [SierraCiesAcChgPen0] when there is an **aircraft change at a base**. 

When an **aircraft change occurs at an outstation**, apply a penalty of [SierraCiesAcChgPen1].

The **total penalty** assigned to a duty is the number of airplane changes in the duty multiplied by the penalty cost. 

[CiesAcChgPenPerCrewMember | switch] Multiply the aircraft change penalty by the number of crew members on the pairing. 

Only apply the aircraft change penalty to connections that are shorter than [CiesAcChgPenConnTimeMin].

[CiesAcChgPenExcludeSplitDuty | switch] Do not apply the penalty to [split duties](split-duty-def).

name: Language position definition
userDescription: The crew positions listed in [SierraPgCrewPositionLanguage this table] are "language positions". These positions will be ignored by the solver when building pairings; but you will be able to use them when manually creating or changing pairings in the user interface.

name: Maximum pairing duration
userDescription:
Limit pairing durations to a maximum of [CiesTripTimeMax]. 

[CiesApplyThrsTrip | switch] Display a caution on pairings that are within [CiesThrsTimeTrip] of the maximum duration. This is a fundamental rule for the solver; it must always be on.

name: Default minimum rest time - CARS 2008
userDescription:
Crew members must have a minimum of [CarDefaultRestTimeMin] after a standard duty. 

This default will be overridden by other minimum rest settings; for example, there is a different minimum rest calculation for rests at outstations in different time zones.

name: Rolling window definition
userDescription: A rolling window is a period of a specific length that shifts relative to the current date. For example, if a rolling window rule limits the maximum amount of flying time in 7 days, on each day of a pairing, the solver will look at the 3 prior and 3 following days, to ensure that there is sufficient rest within those 7 days.

name: Acclimatized definition
userDescription:
A crew member is **acclimatized** when their sleep cycle has adjusted to a location. Once crew are acclimatized to a location, adjustments for DST changes, as well as measurements of time intervals, duty classifications, FDPs, or rest periods, are based on the local time at that location.

All crew are assumed to be acclimatized to their home base at the start of a pairing. The system is updated with the station that a crew member is currently acclimatized to at the start and end of each duty period within a pairing.

name: Acclimatized reference station
userDescription: The acclimatized reference station is the location where the crew member was most recently acclimatized to the local time zone.

name: Acclimatization settings
userDescription:
The following settings control how various calculations related to acclimatization are made.

- [Car700ApplyDSTChgToAcclimClock | switch] Enable DST changes to be factored in when calculating time differences between locations. 
- [Car700ApplyLocalNightWithAcclimInsideRest | switch] When counting local nights in a rest period, check whether a crew member could become acclimatized to their new location part-way through a layover. If so, the local-night count is based on the local time and night window at the layover station. These settings determine how a crew member's acclimatized reference time (the time at the reference station) is updated if there has been a change to/from DST at the [acclimatized reference station](acclimatized-ref-station-cars-def).

The next setting determines how a crew member's acclimatized reference time (the time at the reference station) is updated if there has been a change to/from DST at the [acclimatized reference station](acclimatized-ref-station-cars-def). 

[Car700ApplyDSTChgToAcclimRef | switch] When off, the crew member's acclimatized reference time is not updated until they return to the same time zone as the [acclimatized reference station](acclimatized-ref-station-cars-def). 

When on, regardless of where the crew member is, their acclimatized reference time is updated when they arrive at the next rest or departure location that follows the DST change. This will affect the measurement of start times and intervals for the duty or rest that is about to begin.

name: Window of circadian low (WOCL) definition
userDescription:
The Window of Circadian Low (WOCL) is the period between [SierraCar700WOCL0] and [SierraCar700WOCL1] at the location where the flight crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). 

If at least one minute of a duty occurs during this period, the duty is **encroaching on** or **touching** the WOCL.

name: Local night definition
userDescription: A local night is the period between [SierraCar700LocalNight0] and [SierraCar700LocalNight1] inclusive, at a specific location.

name: Local night's rest definition
userDescription: A local night's rest is a period of at least [Car700LocalNightRest] that occurs during a [local night](local-night-cars-def) at the station where the crew member is acclimatized. Transport to and from the hotel is not included as part of the rest period.

name: Early duty definition
userDescription:
An early duty is a duty period with a report time that occurs between [SierraCar700EarlyStart0] and [SierraCar700EarlyStart1], at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). This includes deadhead-only and standby duties.  

[SierraCar700ApplyEarlyLateNightCaution0 |switch] Display an info icon on pairings that include an early start duty.

name: Late duty definition
userDescription:
A late duty is a duty period with a release time that occurs between [SierraCar700LateFinish0] and [SierraCar700LateFinish1], at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). This includes deadhead-only and standby duties. 

[SierraCar700ApplyEarlyLateNightCaution1 | switch] Display an info icon on pairings that contain a late finish.

name: Night duty definition
userDescription:
A night duty is a duty period with a report time that occurs between [SierraCar700NightDuty0] and [SierraCar700NightDuty1], and that has a release time after [SierraCar700NightDuty2], at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). This includes deadhead-only and standby duties, and all ground duties considered 'hours of work'. 

[SierraCar700ApplyEarlyLateNightCaution2 | switch] Display an info icon on pairings that include a late night duty.

name: Flight duty period (FDP) definition
userDescription: A flight duty period (FDP) is the period that begins when a crew member reports for duty at the start of the briefing period, and ends at the planned arrival time of the last operating flight in the duty.

name: Maximum FDP: CAR 700.28
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~Car700ApplyFDPMaxWithDh param) (~Car700FDPMaxBuffer param) (~Car700FDPMax param) (~SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit0 param) (~Car700FDPMaxBuffer2 param) (~Car700FDPMax2 param) (~SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit0 param) (~SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit1 param) (~Car700FDPMaxBuffer3 param) (~Car700FDPMax3 param) (~SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit1 param) (~Car700ApplyFDPMaxBuffer param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
Apply limits on a crew member's flight duty period (FDP) depending on: 
- The average duration of the planned flights,
- The start time of the FDP at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def), and 
- How many operating flights are in the duty.

[Car700ApplyFDPMaxBuffer | switch] Add buffers to the limits defined below.

1. **700.28 (2)**: When the average duration of operating flights within the duty is less than [SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit1], FDPs will be limited to the maximums defined in [Car700FDPMax3 this table].
If buffers are enabled, the maximum FDP will be reduced based on the number of landings, as defined in [Car700FDPMaxBuffer3 this table].
2. **700.28 (3)**: When the average duration of operating flights within the duty is [SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit1] or more, but less than [SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit0], FDPs will be limited to the maximums defined in [Car700FDPMax2 this table].
If buffers are enabled, the maximum FDP will be reduced based on the number of landings, as defined in [Car700FDPMaxBuffer2 this table].
3. **700.28 (4)**: When the average duration of operating flights within the duty is [SierraCar700FDPMaxAvgLimit0] or longer, FDPs will be limited to the maximums defined in [Car700FDPMax this table].
If buffers are enabled, the above maximum FDP limits will be reduced based on the number of landings, as defined in [Car700FDPMaxBuffer this table].

[Car700ApplyFDPMaxWithDh | switch]When determining the maximum FDP, include deadheads that occur before operating flights in the count of flights.

name: Rest Period - Positioning: CAR 700.43
userDescription:
When a duty ends with one or more deadheads, the flight duty period (FDP) may be extended by a maximum of [Car700ExtensionFDPWithDh]. If the extension is used, the post-duty rest must be at least as long as the duty time.

Duties that consist entirely of deadheads can have a maximum duration of [SierraCar700DutyTimeMaxForDhOnlyDuty0], which can be extended by no more than [SierraCar700DutyTimeMaxForDhOnlyDuty1]. 

If the duration of a deadhead duty is extended beyond the maximum defined above, the next layover must be at least as long as the deadhead duty duration.

name: FDP extension for split duties - CAR 700.50
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~Car700ApplyCautionFDPSplitDuty param) (~Car700FDPSplitDutyIsOneDutyTrip param) (~SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyNight1 param) (~SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyNight0 param) (~Car700ApplyFDPSplitDutyWindDownUpMaxExt param) (~SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor1 param) (~SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor0 param) (~Car700FDPSplitDutyTimes param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
Allow a flight duty period (FDP) to be extended for [split duties](split-duty-def) that have at least one break that provides a sufficiently long rest opportunity.

To qualify for an extension, the time on the ground during the split duty break must allow for:
- A minimum rest period, which can include time for travel to and from the accommodation; *plus*
- Time to wind down and wind up at the accommodation; *plus* 
- Debriefing time prior to the rest period; *plus*
- Briefing time after the rest period.

The minimum durations for these events are specified in [Car700FDPSplitDutyTimes this table]. 

The amount of FDP extension allowed for an eligible split duty depends on when the split-duty break occurs.

If the split duty rest touches the night period, the maximum FDP can be increased by [SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor0] percent. If the rest occurs during the day, the FDP can only be increased by [SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor1] percent.

[Car700ApplyFDPSplitDutyWindDownUpMaxExt | switch] If the split duty break spans day and night, schedule the wind down and wind up periods so that most of the rest time occurs between [SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyNight0] and [SierraCar700FDPSplitDutyNight1]. This will help to maximize the allowed FDP extension.
[Car700FDPSplitDutyIsOneDutyTrip | switch] Split duties can only be one-day pairings that start and end at the same base. 
[Car700ApplyCautionFDPSplitDuty | switch] Generate a caution for an FDP that requires a split-duty extension in order to be legal.

name: Minimum rest at an outstation: CAR 700.40(1)/700.42
userDescription:
When a flight duty period (FDP) ends away from home base, crew members must be given a rest periodbased on the time zone difference (TZD) as follows:
- If the TZD between the start and end of the FDP (in local times) is less than [Car700DutyTimeZoneDifference], the rest following the duty must be at least [SierraCar700RestTimeMin0].
- If the TZD is equal to the above basic setting, the rest following the duty must be at least [SierraCar700RestTimeMin1].
- If the TZD is greater than the above basic setting, the rest following the duty must be at least [SierraCar700RestTimeMin2].

name: Augmented duty definition
userDescription: An augmented duty is a duty period in which extra crew members are added to the standard composition required for a flight.

name: Minimum rest after augmented duty: CAR 700.60(7)
userDescription:
The minimum rest required after an [augmented duty](augmented-duty-def) that ends at an outstation is either [SierraCar700MinRestAfterAugmentedDuty0], or the duration of the augmented duty, whichever is longer.

If an augmented duty ends a home base, the minimum rest is [SierraCar700MinRestAfterAugmentedDuty1] or the duration of the augmented duty, whichever is longer.

name: Minimum rest at home base after FDP: CAR 700.40(1)/700.42
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP3 param) (~SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP2 param) (~SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP1 param) (~SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP0 param) (~SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP2 param) (~SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP1 param) (~SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP0 param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
When a flight duty period (FDP) ends at home base, crew members must be given a rest period that meets these requirements:
- If the time zone difference (TZD) between the start and end of the FDP (in local times) is less than [Car700TimeZoneDifference] ("regular TZD") the minimum rest at home base is [SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP0].
- If the time zone difference is equal to the "regular TZD" and the crew member has been away from home base for [SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDPLimitTAFB0] ("regular TAFB") or less, the minimum rest at home base is [SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP1].
- If the time zone difference is equal to the "regular TZD" and the crew member has been away from home base for more than the "regular TAFB", the minimum rest at home base is [SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDP2].
- If the time zone difference is greater than the "regular TZD" but not more than [Car700LargeTimeZoneDifference] ("large TZD") and the crew member has been away from home base for [SierraCar700MinRestAtHomeBaseAfterFDPLimitTAFB1] ("long TAFB") or less:
   - [SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP0] nights of [local rest](local-night-rest-cars-def) are required, as long as no part of the FDP touches the [WOCL](wocl-cars-def);
   - If any part of the FDP touches the WOCL, the duty must be followed by [SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP1] local nights of rest at home base.
- If the time zone difference is greater than the "large TZD" and the crew member has been away from home base for a "long TAFB" or less, the duty must be followed by [SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP2]  nights of local rest at home base.
- If the time zone difference is greater than the "large TZD" and the crew member has been away from home base for more than the "long TAFB", the duty must be followed by [SierraCar700MinLocalNightsAtHomeBaseAfterFDP3] nights of local rest at home base.

name: Local nights between duty transitions: CAR 700.41
userDescription:
There must be a minimum of [Car700LocalNightMinForDisruption] local nights of rest between two flight duty periods (FDPs) when a crew member is transitioning from a [late duty](late-duty-cars-def) or [night duty](night-duty-cars-def) to an [early duty](early-duty-cars-def), or vice versa. 

This rule does not apply when a crew member starts a duty in a location where there is more than [Car700TimeDifferenceForDisruption] hours of difference between the crew member's current location, and the last location that they were [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def) to. 

[Car700UseMinRestDisruptionForDhdOnly | switch] Apply this rule to duties that contain only deadheads. When off, the rule is applied only when both duties before and after a rest period are not deadhead-only.

name: Maximum duty hours in X hours: CAR 700.29(c)
userDescription: A crew member can be rostered no more than [SierraCar700MaxDutyHoursInXHours0] of duty within any period of [SierraCar700MaxDutyHoursInXHours1] consecutive hours.

name: Single day off in X hours: CAR 700.29(c-i)
userDescription: Crew members must have a minimum of 1 day off (at any station) within any period of [Car700SingleDayOffInXHours] consecutive hours.

name: Limit consecutive WOCL FDPs: CAR 700.51
userDescription:
1. A crew member can be assigned up to [Car700ConsecutiveWOCLMax] consecutive [flight duty periods (FDPs)](fdp-def) that touch the [WOCL](wocl-cars-def). 
After this maximum has been reached, the next WOCL period cannot be touched by an FDP. At least [Car700ConsecutiveWOCLNightRest] [local night's rest](local-night-rest-cars-def) is required before another WOCL FDP can be assigned to the crew member.
2. The limit on consecutive FDPs that touch the WOCL can be extended to a maximum of [Car700ConsecutiveWOCLExtendedMax] if the following conditions are met:
	- Each of the FDPs in the sequence includes a rest of at least [Car700ConsecutiveWOCLExtendedBreakInFDP] in a hotel or other suitable accommodation, not including the travel time to/from the rest facility between flights.
	- After the last FDP in the sequence, a crew member must have a period "free-from-duty" of at least [Car700ConsecutiveWOCLExtendedTimeFreeFromDuty].

name: Limit maximum duty time
userDescription: Duties that have at least one operating flight cannot be longer than [SierraCiesDutyTimeMaxActDh0]. Deadhead-only duties cannot be longer than [SierraCiesDutyTimeMaxActDh1].

name: Acclimatizing interval definition: CAR 700.28(5)
userDescription:
The **acclimatizing interval** is the length of time that crew must be in a new geographic zone before they are considered to be acclimatized to that zone. 

Enter a value of 0 or 1 here [Car700AcclimatizingIntervalRefOption] to specify how the interval will be determined:
- If you enter 0, the interval will be the difference in the number of geographic zones between the location where crew members were last [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def) and the last rest location. DST changes are not a factor.
- If you enter 1, the interval will be the difference in local time between the location where crew members were last [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def) and their current location; and DST changes can affect the measurement.

The amount of time required for crew members to acclimatize to a new zone is defined in [Car700MinTimeRequiredForAcclimatization this table].

name: Flight-to-base associations
userDescription:
Associate operating flights to one or more crew bases. Two types of associations are supported:
- **Impose**: Forces the flights to be included in pairings domiciled at the associated bases. 
- **Forbid**: Disallows the flights from being included in pairings domiciled at the associated bases. 

Current associations:
- **By-flight**: Direct associations based on the flights in this scenario are defined in [flightDomicileByMatch this table]
- **By-filter**: Indirect associations based on the saved filters in this scenario are in [flightDomicileByFilter this table]

To create new by-flight associations, go the pairings page, select one or more operating flights, then right-click and select **Associate to base stations** from the pop-up menu.

name: Early duty definition
userDescription:
An early duty is a duty period with a report time that occurs between [SierraCar700EarlyStart0] and [SierraCar700EarlyStart1], at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). This includes deadhead-only and standby duties.  
[SierraCar700ApplyEarlyLateNightCaution0 |switch]Display an info icon on pairings that include an early start duty.

name: Night duty definition
userDescription:
A night duty is a duty period with a report time that occurs between [SierraCar700NightDuty0] and [SierraCar700NightDuty1], and that has a release time after [SierraCar700NightDuty2], at the location where the crew member is [acclimatized](acclimatized-cars-def). This includes deadhead-only and standby duties, and all ground duties considered hours of work. 
[SierraCar700ApplyEarlyLateNightCaution2 | switch]Display an info icon on pairings that include a late night duty.

name: Reduce rest duration by transit times
userDescription: Deduct the time it takes to travel between the airport and the hotel during a layover when calculating rest time.

name: Minimum rest in 7 days: CAR 700.19(1)(a) - 2008
userDescription:
Crew members must have a minimum of [CarRestTimeMinIn168H] of rest within any period of 7 consecutive days. 

[CarApplyThrsRestTimeMinIn168H | switch]Reject any pairings that are within [CarThrsRestTimeMinIn168H] of preventing a crew member from getting their minimum required rest.

name: Number of crew on duty per day
userDescription: The number of pairings operating on any given day cannot exceed the number of crew who are available on that day, as defined in [CiesCrewAvailPerPosPerBase this table].

name: Minimum average block hour productivity targets
userDescription:
Build pairings with an average block hour productivity of at least [SierraCiesGlobalProdMinAllBases], across all crew bases.

Measure block hour productivity as block hours per [CiesApplyGlobalProdOnDutyDays | duty day | duty period].

[CiesApplyGlobalProdWithCDO |switch] Include flying time on [CDOs](cdo-pairing-def) when calculating the average amount of flying time to be covered by each base on each day.

[CiesApplyGlobalProdMinPerBase |switch] Instead of a single global productivity target, aim for the minimums defined per base in [CiesGlobalProdMin this table].

name: Minimum/maximum credit time targets
userDescription:
Distribute pairing credit hours across crew bases according to [CiesGlobalSoftCreditMinPerPos this table], which defines minimum daily target values for each combination of base and position. 

Target daily credit hour maximums for each base/position combination are defined in [CiesGlobalSoftCreditMaxPerPos this table].

name: Minimum/maximum block time targets
userDescription:
Distribute pairing block hours across crew bases according to [CiesGlobalSoftBlockMinPerPos this table], which defines minimum daily target values for each combination of base and position. 

Target daily block hour maximums for each base/position combination are defined in [CiesGlobalSoftBlockMaxPerPos this table].

name: Minimum percentage of pairings of different durations
userDescription:
The minimum desired percentage of pairings of different sizes (duty days or duty periods) are defined in [SierraCiesGlobalPercentMinTripDutyDay this table]. 

Enter a percentage value between 0 and 100 wherever a minimum target is desired (for example: enter 55 for 55%). 
Leave a cell blank to specify no minimum for that combination of base/number of duty days. This means that the amount allocated can be as low as 0 pairings (0%).

When filling out this table, note that:
- The last column includes pairings with at least the number of days as the column label. For example, if the last column is labelled "4", the percentages in that column are for pairings that touch 4 or more calendar days.
- The values entered in any row cannot add up to more than 100%

Calculate minimum/maximum percentages based on [CiesApplyGlobalPercentTripDutyDayOnDutyDays | duty days | duty periods]. Note: This setting is shared between the minimum and maximum targets on percentages of pairings of different durations.

[CiesApplyGlobalPercentTripDutyDayPerBase | switch] Use the total number of pairings at each base to calculate the percent distribution, for the minimum and maximum targets. Turn this option off to use the total of all pairings for the crew group instead. In this case, only the first row of the target table will be considered.

name: Maximum percentage of pairings of different durations
userDescription:
The maximum desired percentage of pairings of different sizes (duty days or duty periods) are defined in [SierraCiesGlobalPercentMaxTripDutyDay this table]. 

Enter a percentage value between 0 and 100 wherever a maximum target is desired (for example, enter 55 for 55%). Leave a cell blank to specify no maximum for that combination of base/number of duty days. This means that the amount allocated can be as high as all of the pairings (100%).

When filling out this table, note that:
- The last column in the table includes pairings with at least the number of days as the column label. For example, if the last column is labelled "4", the percentages in that column are for pairings that touch 4 or more calendar days.
- If all of the cells in a row are filled (not blank), the values in that row must add up to at least 100%.
Calculate minimum/maximum percentages based on [CiesApplyGlobalPercentTripDutyDayOnDutyDays | duty days | duty periods]. Note: This setting is shared between the minimum and maximum targets on percentages of pairings of different durations.

[CiesApplyGlobalPercentTripDutyDayPerBase | switch] Use the total number of pairings at each base to calculate the percent distribution, for the minimum and maximum targets. Turn this option off to use the total of all pairings for the crew group instead.  In this case, only the first row of the target table will be considered.

name: Hard limit for jumpseats
userDescription: Do not use a non-operating flight for positioning if there are no available jumpseats on that flight.

name: Forbid flights to/from specific stations per base
userDescription: When building a pairing, do not include operating flights to/from specific stations, depending on the pairing's crew base, as defined in [CiesForbiddenStationsPerBase this table].

name: Earliest departure time for long pairings
userDescription: Pairings that are longer than  [CiesLongTripDayDepartureLength] days cannot start before [CiesLongTripDayDepartureTime].

name: Deadhead sequences can only visit a station once
userDescription: Do not allow any station to be visited more than once within the same deadhead sequence. A warning is generated when this rule is violated.

name: Forbid internal deadheads on flights with specific service types
userDescription: Do not allow crew members to deadhead on company flights that have any of the service types in [CiesForbidDhLegTypes this table].

name: FDP max soft buffer caution
userDescription: Apply soft buffer for going over maximum FDP by a value of [Car700FDPMaxSoftBuffer] (between 0h00 and 5h00)

name: Non linear penalty for excceding FDP max soft buffer
userDescription:
Apply penalty for going over FDP max and its soft maximum. The penalty is defined in [Car700FDPMaxSoftBufferNonLinearPenalty this table]. 
It consists of two values: the first (Penalty cost) is the cost of the non linear penalty, and the second (Penalty factor) is the factor used to calculate the penalty.
As a result, Extra time over the soft maximum FDP is raised to the penalty factor and the result is multiplied by the cost of the penalty.

name: Deadhead time credit
userDescription: The block time of a deadhead is multiplied by [CieCreditFactorDh] to get the leg credits

name: Global maximum duty day hard limit per base
userDescription: [CiesApplyGlobalDutyDayMaxPerDayHardZeroLimit This table] allows to prevent or permit the construction of trips that need some number of crew positions on certain days for a certain base, but the available positions on those trip days (crew availability) are not enough to cover the crew requirement of the trip

name: Hotel override caution display
userDescription: Turn on to display cautions on hotel override in pairings

name: Undefined hotel override caution display
userDescription: Turn on to display cautions on undefined hotel override in pairings

name: Include rest before and after trip in duty days
userDescription:
Apply this rule to include the rest before or after the pairing in the number of duty days taken by the trip.

The length of the trip will be extended by half of the values in [CiesRestBeforeAfterTrip this table] so the calculation of the duty days in the trip contains the extra duty days that can occue

The time spent during layover at base is multiplied by [CiesExtraDutyDayFactor]

[CiesRestAfterTripByDebriefing This parameter] is used to set the rest before after trip by debriefing time. The system will also use the value of this parameter for the rest after trip by taking the maximum value of this parameter and [CiesRestBeforeAfterTrip the table defined above]

[CiesRestBeforeAfterTripFlightExceptions this parameter] contains the values for the rest at home base before or after a trip that starts or ends with a specific flight number

name: Minimum/maximum block time targets as percentages
userDescription:
When applied, the global constrainst on block time will be calculated with the maximim and minimum percentage parameters.

Maximum percentage of block time permitteed for each base and position used is defined in [CiesGlobalSoftBlockPercentMaxPerPos this table]

Minimum percentage of block time permitteed for each base and position used is defined in [CiesGlobalSoftBlockPercentMinPerPos this table]

name: Maximum number of landings in the last 24 hours
userDescription: Apply the rule that prevents having more than [CiesMaxLandingsIn24H this table] landings in the last 24 hours.

name: EASA - Maximum FDP duration
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~EasaFDPMax param) (~EasaAugFDPMax param) (~EasaApplyFDPMaxWithDhd param) (~EasaApplyFDPMaxWithGnd param) (~EasaAugDutyActLegMax param) (~EasaSingleAugDutyInFlightRestMinLandingCrew param) (~EasaSingleAugDutyInFlightRestMinNonLandingCrew param) (~EasaDoubleAugDutyInFlightRestMinLandingCrew param) (~EasaDoubleAugDutyInFlightRestMinNonLandingCrew param) (~EasaApplyAugmentedDutyCaution param) (~EasaFDPMaxNonAccl param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
The maximum FDP depends on the local departure time of the duty and the number of sectors in the duty.

The maximum FDP is defined in [EasaFDPMax this EASA FDP max table]

For crew members that are not acclimatized the FDP limitation, depending on the number of sectors, is given in [EasaFDPMaxNonAccl this table]

[EasaApplyFDPMaxWithDhd | switch] Include deadheads in the number of sectors in a duty for maximum FDP

[EasaApplyFDPMaxWithGnd | switch ] Include ground movements in the number of sectors in a duty for maximum

### Augmentation

For the augmented FDP, [EasaAugFDPMax this table] defines the FDP limitation table which depends on the rest facility. This table is used no matter if the crew is acclimatised or not.

The maximum number of active segments in an augmented duty is [EasaAugDutyActLegMax]

The duration of the in-flight rest on a leg is the duration of this leg, minus the time for ascent and descent.  These durations will be subtracted form the FDP in the calculation of the in-flight rest (for augmentation).  The duration of the inflight rest for pilots at the controls should be greater or equal to the inflight rest of the extra pilots.

**Single augmented duty**: The minimum in-flight rest for pilots manipulating controls is [EasaSingleAugDutyInFlightRestMinLandingCrew], and [EasaSingleAugDutyInFlightRestMinNonLandingCrew] for the extra pilots

**Double augmented duty**: The minimum in-flight rest for pilots manipulating controls is [EasaDoubleAugDutyInFlightRestMinLandingCrew], and [EasaDoubleAugDutyInFlightRestMinNonLandingCrew] for the extra pilots

[EasaApplyAugmentedDutyCaution | switch] Display caution on augmented duties

name: EASA - Use the Ground Delay in FDP Max Rule
userDescription:
The maximum FDP time allowed will be lowered by the ground delay value defined [CiesGroundDelayDutyTimeReduction in this table].

Applying this rule will allow only shorter FDP when ground delay is positive.

name: EASA - Include deadheads at the end of a duty in the calculation of the duration of the FDP
userDescription: When this rule is activated, deadheads after the last active flight of a duty count in the duration of the FDP.

name: EASA - Include debriefing at the end of a duty in the calculation of the duration of the FDP
userDescription: When this rule is activated, the debriefing of a duty counts in the duration of the FDP.

name: EASA - Take the briefing time of pilots instead of FA in the determination of the maximum FDP
userDescription:
When this rule is activated, the solver will determine the maximum FDP according to the departure time of the pilots instead of the departure time of the FA. 

For Flight attendants, if they start their duty before the pilots, the maximum FDP can be extend by the difference in reporting time between cabin crew and pilots, as long as the difference does not exceed the value defined by [EasaMaxAdjustDepTimeForFAForFDP this parameter]

The rule to [Apply flight deck rules during the solve](CiesApplyCockpitCrew) must be off to indicate that the scenario is a flight attendant scenario.

name: EASA - Maximum FDP buffer duration
userDescription:
When this rule is activated, the FDP buffer is applied.
This buffer depends on the number of sectors in a duty.

For acclimatized crew, the FDP buffer is defined in [EasaFDPMaxBuffer this table]

For non acclimatized crew, the FDP buffer is defined in [EasaFDPMaxNonAcclBuffer this table]

The maximum FDP is reduced by the corresponding entries in the tables.

name: EASA - Toggle on FDP extension
userDescription:
When this rule is activated, the FDP extension is allowed

The [EasaExtendedFDPMax EASA extended fdp max table] defines the extended FDP limitation which depends on both the local start time of the FDP and the number of sectors where the crew member is acclimatized. 

[EasaApplyCautionFDPExtension | switch ] Display a caution on pairing when an FDP needs extension to be legal

name: EASA - Toggle on FDP extension for Augmented duties with 1 long sector
userDescription:
Applying this rule allows the FDP max augmentation extension for 1 long flight.

The limits defined by the [EasaAugFDPMax augmented EASA FDP max table] can be increased by [EasaExtendedAugFDPExtension] for FDPs that include one sector of more than [EasaExtendedAugFDPMinFlightDuration] of continuous flight time and a maximum of [EasaExtendedAugFDPMaxSectors] sectors.

name: EASA - Use Extended Maximum FDP as Max. Duty Time for active duties ending in a deadhead
userDescription:
When this rule is applied, the duty time of active duties ending in a deadhead is checked against the maximum FDP plus an extension. 

If the normal rule on Maximum Duty Time is also enabled, it is not applied to active duties ending in deadhead. 
For this rule to take effect, the rule [Easa Apply FDP Max](EasaApplyFDPMax) must also be activated.

The Maximum FDP extension to use as maximum duty time for active duties ending with deadhead is [EasaDutyTimeMaxEndDhdUseFDPExtension].

name: EASA - Toggle on Maximum Duty duration
userDescription: Apply this rule to limit the maximum duty time to the value [EasaDutyTimeMax]

name: EASA - Use the Ground Delay in Duty Time Max Rule
userDescription: Apply this rule to lower the allowed maximum duty time by the ground delay value defined [CiesGroundDelayDutyTimeReduction in this table]

name: EASA - Apply Maximum Number of Sectors in a FDP When Encroachment With WOCL
userDescription:
Apply this rule to limit the duration of FDP that encroaches the WOCL window

When the FDP does not encroach the WOCL, then the FDP extension is limited to FDP with up to [EasaFDPExtensionMaxSectorNoWOCLEncroachment] sectors.

When an FDP encroaches on the WOCL by up to the value of the parameter [EasaFDPExtensionWOCL], the FDP extension is limited to FDP with up to [EasaFDPExtensionMaxSectorMinorWOCLEncroachment] sectors

When an FDP encroaches on the WOCL by more than the value of the parameter [EasaFDPExtensionWOCL], the FDP extension is limited to FDP with up to  [EasaFDPExtensionMaxSectorMajorWOCLEncroachment] sectors.

name: EASA - Print FDP statistics in the trip report
userDescription: Print statistics on FDP in the trip report.

name: EASA - Minimum Rest Duration
userDescription:
This parameter allows the user to turn on or off the rule on minimum layover duration. Effects: When the parameter is set to Yes, every layover is checked against the minimum duration allowed.

This rule limits the layover duration.

The minimum rest away from base must be as long as the maximum between [EasaRestTimeMinAwayfromBase] and the previous duty period.

The minimum rest at home base must be as long as the maximum between [EasaRestTimeMinBase] and the previous duty period.

A buffer value of [EasaRestTimeMinBuffer] is added to the maximum value defined above.

The system will take the maximum between this rule and the value given in the [SierraLayoverTimeMin generoc layover time table]

name: EASA - Apply the increase of rest due to FDP extension rule
userDescription:
When this rule is applied, the minimum rest before and after an extended FDP must be increased.

When an FDP is planned to use an extension, pre and post flight minimum rests are increased by the values defined in [EasaIncreaseRestWhenFDPExtended this table], whether the first or second rows.

Where the extensions are used for consecutive FDPs, the pre and post rest between the two operations shall run consecutively.

The system will decide which one of both possibilities is the best to ensure that the pre and post layover are legal.

name: EASA - Apply the rule of Maximum Number of FDP Extensions in any 7 consecutive days
userDescription: Apply this rule to limit the maximum number of FDP extensions in any 7 consecutive days to [EasaMaxNbFDPExtensionsIn7Days].

name: EASA - Apply the rule of Maximum Duty Hours in any 7 Consecutive Days
userDescription:
Apply this rule to limit the maximum duty hours in any 7 consecutive days to [EasaMaxDutyHoursIn7Days].

[EasaApplyGroundDelayToMaxDutyHoursIn7Days | switch] Apply a ground delay reduction of [CiesGroundDelayDutyTimeReduction] to the maximum duty hours above

[EasaApplyMaxDutyHoursIn7DaysCaution | switch] Display caution where duty hours in 7 consecutive days is [EasaMaxDutyHoursIn7DaysThreshold] away from  maximum value.

name: EASA - Apply the rule of Maximum Duty Hours in any 14 Consecutive Days
userDescription:
Apply this rule to limit the maximum duty hours in any 14 consecutive days to [EasaMaxDutyHoursIn14Days].

[EasaApplyGroundDelayToMaxDutyHoursIn14Days | switch] Apply a ground delay reduction of [CiesGroundDelayDutyTimeReduction] to the maximum duty hours above

[EasaApplyMaxDutyHoursIn14DaysCaution | switch] Display caution where duty hours in 14 consecutive days is [EasaMaxDutyHoursIn14DaysThreshold] away from  maximum value.

name: EASA - Apply The generation of EASA augmentation flag
userDescription: When this rule is applied, the EASA crew augmentation will be set dynamically on the legs. Thus, the EASA rules will be validated according to this new assignation of crew augmentation instead of the current crew composition of the leg.

name: EASA - Apply FDP extension due to split duty
text: (pairing-program (extension-functions ((hbr) (when (and #f (~EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesMinBreakDuration param) (~EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesPreFlightDuration param) (~EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesPostFlightDuration param) (~EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesMaxBreakDuration param) (~EasaFDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor param) (~EasaFDPSplitDutyIsOneDutyTrip param) (~EasaApplyCautionFDPSplitDuty param)) (info "")))))
userDescription:
When this rule is applied, the FDP max be extended if the duty is a split duty.

### Calculation of the FDP extension for split duties

The break on the ground within the FDP must have a minimum of [EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesMinBreakDuration].

The break excludes the time allowed for pre flight, defined as [EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesPreFlightDuration], and post flight, defined as [EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesPostFlightDuration].

The maximum FDP may be increased by up to the percentage of [EasaFDPSplitDutyExtensionFactor].

Any break exceeding [EasaFDPSplitDutyTimesMaxBreakDuration] or any time of the break that encroaches the WOCL does not count for the extension of the FDP.



[EasaFDPSplitDutyIsOneDutyTrip | switch] Split duty must be a one duty trip starting and ending at the same base

[EasaApplyCautionFDPSplitDuty | switch] Display caution on FDP that needs split duty extension to be legal

name: EASA - Apply the rule on minimum weekly rest (Recurrent extended recovery rest period)
userDescription:
When this rule is applied, two consecutive Recurrent Extended Recovery Rest Periods (RERRP) should be separated by a period of no more than [EasaWeeklyRestTimeMaxCons].

A RERRP is a layover of at least [EasaWeeklyRestTimeMin] including [EasaWeeklyRestLocalNightMin] local nights.

If the period between tow consecutive RERRP contains at least [EasaExtendedWeeklyRestNbDutyMin] disruptive duties (early.late or night duty), then the second RERRP must be at least [EasaExtendedWeeklyRestTimeMin].

name: EASA - Apply penalty for augmented duty
userDescription:
Apply penalty to a duty requiring augmented crew.

The amount of penalty applied is the total leg credits of the duty multiplied by the cost per min per additional member (currently just 3rd pilot).  It is possible to also add a supplementary penalty to approximate additional costs, such as per diem.

The penalty on a duty which is set to [EasaAugDutyPenalty].
This penalty can be used for approximating additional costs that come with an extra crew member, such per diem.
If this value is 0, then the penalty applied is just the duty credits * cost per min of third pilot.

name: EASA - Apply the rule to forbid augmentation on domestic duties
userDescription: When this rule is applied, a domestic duty cannot be augmented. Also, the last active segment in an augmented duty cannot be domestic.

name: EASA - Toggle on Maximum Number of Operating Sectors in a Night Duty
userDescription: When this rule is applied, the maximum number of operating sectors in a night duty is limited to [EasaNightDutyActSectorMax].

name: EASA - Transitions between Early, Late, Day and Night duties in a trip
userDescription:
This rule allows the user to turn on or off the verification on transition between Early and Night duty, between Late and Early duty, between Night and other than night duty, or any other type of combination. This rule also controls restrictions on consecutive night start duties.

[EasaStartDutyTypeTransitionDomInt This table]  allows the user to turn on or off the verification on transition between Early, Day, Late and Night duty, between domestic and international duties.

[EasaMinRestBetweenStartDutyType This table] defines the minimum rest time between any kind of duty: Early start duty, Day start duty, Late start duty and Night start duty. A very large value means that the transition between two start duty types is forbidden.

The maximum rest time between consecutive night start duties is [EasaConsNightStartDutyRest]

The maximum is number of consecutive night start duties is [EasaMaxConsNightStartDutyNb]

name: EASA - Toggle on Acclimatization
userDescription:
This rule allows the user to turn on or off The verification on acclimatization.

When the rule is not applied, the number of time zones crossed by a duty or a trip is not taken into account. So all stations are considered in the same acclimatized time zone, and the reference time of a duty is then always the local time at the departure of this duty.

[EasaAcclimatizationState This parameter] defines the state of acclimatization, depending on time difference between reference location and current location and the time elapsed since the first briefing at the reference location.
"B" means acclimatized to the local time of the reference time zone
"D" means acclimatized to the local time where the crew members start the current duty
"X" means that the crew members is in an unknown state of acclimatization

name: EASA - Toggle on minimum rest in a outstation after time zone differences
userDescription:
When this rule is activated, the minimum rest after a duty/FDP involving time zone difference is applied.

If a duty/FDP involves at least [EasaTimeZoneDiffMin] time zones difference between the beginning and the end of this duty/FDP, then a compensated minimum rest of [EasaOutstationRestTimeAfterTimeZoneDiff] must be allowed after this duty/FDP

name: EASA - Switch for verification of minimum rest after crossing many time zones on duty or FDP
userDescription:
The validation of minimum rest after crossing multiple time zones can be determined according to the previous duty or previous FDP.

Apply this rule to validate minimum rest according to previous FDP. When this rule is not activated, the validation is done according to the previous duty.

name: EASA - Apply the rule on minimum rest following an augmented duty
userDescription: When this rule is applied, the minimum rest after an augmented duty must be at least as long as the preceding duty period or the value [EasaRestTimeMinAfterAugDuty].

name: EASA - Definition of EASA Local night
userDescription: A local night is defined as a period of [EasaLocalNightMin] in the time window from [EasaLocalNightLowerBound] to [EasaLocalNightUpperBound]

name: EASA - Window Of Circadian Low
userDescription: The window of circadian low start at [EasaWOCLLowerBound] and ends at [EasaWOCLUpperBound]

name: EASA - Early Start duty definition
userDescription:
An early start duty is a duty that starts between [EasaEarlyStartLowerBound] and [EasaEarlyStartUpperBound]
The reference time at the departure station is used for determining an early start duty.

[EasaApplyEarlyStartCaution | switch] Display caution on early start duties

name: EASA - Easa late finish duty definition
userDescription:
A late finish duty is a duty that ends between [EasaLateFinishLowerBound] and [EasaLateFinishUpperBound]. 
The reference time at the arrival station is used for determining a Late Finish Duty.

[EasaApplyLateFinishCaution | switch] Display caution on late finish duties.

name: EASA - Easa night duty definition
userDescription:
A night duty is a duty that touches the time window from [EasaNightDutyLowerBound] to [EasaNightDutyUpperBound].
The reference time at the departure station of the duty is used for determining a night duty.

[EasaApplyNightDutyCaution | switch] Display caution on night duties

name: EASA - Easa early, day, late, night duty start definition
userDescription:
An early duty is a duty that starts in a time window from [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeEarly] inclusively, up to [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeDay] exclusively

A day duty is a duty that starts in a time window from [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeDay] inclusively, up to [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeLate] exclusively

A late duty is a duty that starts in a time window from [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeLate] inclusively, up to [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeNight] exclusively

A night duty is a duty that starts in a time window from [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeNight] inclusively, up to [EasaStartDutyTypeTimeRangeEarly] exclusively

The reference time at the start of the duty is used for determining the start duty type
